Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Efficient Solvers for Nonlinear Eigenvalue Problems and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves the development of advanced computational methods for solving genuine nonlinear eigenvalue problems. In this project, skillful combination of Kublanovskaya's nonlinear QR algorithm with modern rank-revealing and structure-preserving techniques for small and medium size dense problems enhances the capabilities of new methods. A novel trimmed linearization via Pade rational approximation extends the enhancements for solving large but sparse problems. The investigators seek to develop a systematic and unified treatment of the relevant mathematical theory, and produce numerical methods and software tools for the genuine nonlinear eigenvalue problems. In addition to advancing research in nonlinear eigenvalue problems, the project provides training for graduate students in computational mathematics and interdisciplinary research tools.

Eigenvalue problems are ubiquitous in computational science and engineering, where they arise in the study of dynamics of structures, simulation of nanostructured photovoltaic conversion materials to advance energy science, and many other scenarios. Eigenvalues explain a wide range of physical phenomena such as vibrations and frequencies, (in)stabilities of dynamical systems, and energy excitation states of electrons and molecules. Many eigenvalue problems occur naturally in nonlinear form. In this project, the investigators study the underlying nonlinear problems without relying on linearization approximations. The promise of substantially improved methods for computing solutions of nonlinear eigenvalue problems, brings immediate benefits to a wide range of practical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eigenvalue problems are ubiquitous in computational science and engineering, where they arise in the study of dynamics of structures, simulation of nanostructured photovoltaic conversion materials to advance energy science, and many other scenarios. Eigenvalues explain a wide range of physical phenomena such as vibrations and frequencies,(in)stabilities of dynamical systems, and energy excitation states of electrons and molecules. This project has achieved the following significant outcomes:

1. An efficient nonlinear QR algorithm which skillfullly combines with modern rank-revealing and structure-preserving technqiues. The new method is designed for problems too large to use dense techniques.  For unstructurally banded problems, a new data structure is used for  storing matrices for low memory and computational costs. In addition,  a deflation technique is presented for computing several nearby eigenvalues to already computed ones. The source code has been made publicly available.

2. We developed a Pade Approximate Linearization (PAL) to solve quadratic eigenvalue problems (QEPs) with low-rank damping term. One main advantage  of the PAL algorithm is that the dimension of the resulting linear eigenvalue  problem is only n+ k*m, which is substantially smaller than the dimension 2*n produced by direct linearization approaches, where n is the dimension of the QEP, k and m are the rank of the damping matrix and the order of a Pade approximant,  respectively. Numerical examples show that by exploiting the low-rank damping property, the PAL algorithm runs 33--47% faster. During the course of this work,  we worked closely with computational engineers in designing and tuning the new  algorithm and tested their performance in practical applications.

3. During the course of the project, we have learned the importance of linear response eigenvalue problems (LREPs) arising from excited states calculations in the time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) in computational materials science. There are a great deal of recent work and interests in developing efficient simulation techniques for excitation state
calculations of molecules for materials design in energy science. TD-DFT is an extension of DFT, a nonlinear eigenvalue problem. We conducted  a systematical study of mathematical theory, algorithms and applications of
LREPs.  We uncovered new variational principles to characterize the eigenvalues  and eigenvectors. Although LREPs are non-Hermitian problems, these theoretical  results mirror the well-known results for Hermitian eigenvalue problems. With these  new theoretical results, we developed the best approximation for the desired eigenvalues via structure-preserving subspace projection, and derived locally optimal steepest descent and conjugate gradient-like algorithms using a novel 4D search idea. With our collaborators in chemisty and physics, we have successfully demonstrated the efficiency of new algorithms for excited states calculations of large scale molecular systems. The largest dimension of linear response eigenvalue problems we have solved is 22 millions for fullrence C60.

4. The outcomes of this project advanced our understanding and eigen-solution techniques. Four graduate students have participated the different stage of this project, received train and experience in interdisciplinary computational mathematics.
